questions.text: The reproductive reserve of a female is being tested using the follicular cell count. What is the normal size of a follicular cell?
questions.solution:
These cells are the primordial follicles. They are formed during intrauterine life and are present in the female throughout life; however the number decreases with age and is one of the indicators of reproductive reserve and ageing.

The normal size: 0.03-0.05 mm

Conditions like PCOS etc are linked to dysfunction of the primordial follicles.

Reference: Williams gynecology, 4th edition, chapter 16 page number:349- page number 351.

choices.text: Both lean and obese patients of PCOS can be insulin resistant
Infertility is seen in 80% untreated cases
Necklace pattern of ovary in USG
3x more preantral and antral follicles than normal

questions.text: Which of the following is false about PCOS:
questions.solution:
Infertility is seen in 100% of cases due to higher LH levels which prevent LH surge which in turn results in anovulation. Thus infertility is always [100% cases] a feature of PCOS if untreated.

Incorrect answers:

A: both lean and obese patients show insulin resistance as well as hyperinsulinemia

C: necklace pattern is seen in in USG due to the peripheral arrangement of cysts.

D: the preantral and antral follicles are over three times more than normal adding to the increased volume of the ovaries.

Reference: William's Gynecology, 4th edition, chapter 18 page number:391-393.

choices.text: 14 year old with amenorrhea along with S testosterone 60ng/dl, 10 cysts of 4 mm in right ovary
17 year old with oligomenorrhea with S. testosterone 210 ng/dl with 6 cysts in both right and left ovaries 8mm in size
15 year old with oligomenorrhea with S. testosterone 90 ng/dl with ovaries 12 ml in size
15 year old with regular menses, S testosterone 100 ng/dl with ovaries 9 ml in size

questions.text: Which of the following gives a positive diagnosis for Rotterdam Criteria?
questions.solution:
The Rotterdam criteria gives the diagnosis of PCOS. Here any two out of the three criteria ought to be present.

Thus option C is the appropriate one ticking all of the three criteria.

Incorrect options

A: cysts though >2 mm in size are fewer in number < 12 and only in one ovary.

B: Sr. testosterone above 150 ng/dl is suggestive of androgen secreting tumor

D: regular meses with normal ovarian volume.

Reference: William's gynecology, 4th edition, chapter 18, page number:390-392.

This is based on the embryological origin of the various parts of the vulva, which undergo pathology during vulvar carcinoma.

The development of the labia minora occurs from the genital folds.

Incorrect answers:

A: labia majora develop from the genital swellings. Also known as the labioscrotal swellings, being the female homologue of the scrotum of males.

C: the urogenital sinus develops in the vestibule. It does not give rise to the clitoris.

D: clitoris develops from the genital tubercle and not the genital swellings

The table below mentions all the homologous structures of male and female reproductive system and their origin.

References : D.C. Dutta textbook of gynecology. Chapter 3, development of genital organs and gonads, page number:26

choices.text: Inhibin B: secreted by corpus luteum
Inhibin A: 1st peak during midfollicular phase
Inhibin A: has only one peak

questions.solution:
Inhibin is one of the gonadal peptide secreted. It has two: alpha and beta subunits; and 2 forms inhibin A and B.

They are secreted under the effect of the hormones LH and FSH.

Inhibin A: released from corpus luteum in luteal phase. Under the influence of LH.

It peaks only once i.e. during the mid luteal phase during normal menstruation and is secreted by the placenta during pregnancy. (Option B)

Incorrect answers:

A: Inhibin B is secreted by the granulosa cells in proliferative stage under effect of FSH

B: There is only one peak: during the mid luteal phase.

C: Inhibin B is low during pregnancy

Reference: William's gynecology, 4th edition chapter 16 page number:353- 354.

questions.text: All of the following investigations are recommended in a 15 year old presenting with metrorrhagia except?
questions.solution:
C: Usually in the puberty age group, the endometrial biopsy is not done.

  • It is commonly done for reproductive age group or post menopausal women
  • Other tests never done:
    • PV examination
    • D&C.

Incorrect answers:

Tests recommended to be done are:

  • TVS, TSH: for all age groups.
  • Bleeding profile(Option A)
  • Progesterone: between days 22-24(Option B)
  • pregnancy test if patient is sexually active.
  • Culture for Gonorrhoea and Chlamydia.(Option D)

Reference: William's gynecology, 4th edition, chapter 8, page number:180-190.

questions.text: A patient presents with features of hirsutism, acne and irregular menstrual cycle. The AFP and HCG are not elevated. The USG shows an ovarian mass. Which of the following is the implicated gene mutation if the lesion is theca cell origin and not granulosa cell ?
questions.solution:
The theca cells express all of the enzymes needed to produce androstenedione. This includes high levels of CYP17 expression, whose enzyme product catalyzes 17-hydroxylation. This is the rate limiting step in the conversion of progesterone to androgens.

These androgens are the cause for hirsutism, acne and irregular menstrual cycles.

Reference: Williams Gynaecology, 4th edition, page number:350.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl is brought to the OPD for treatment of dysmenorrhea. Her cycle is regular but painful. She appears disproportionately advanced on the Tanner scale and has a high BMI. Which of the following is responsible?
questions.solution:
The HPO axis functions with pulsatile releases of GnRH, as well as various neurotransmitters.

In obese females, the changes of puberty occur early and are advanced due to the effect of leptin. There is an in increase in the leptin released which causes an acceleration in the onset and features of puberty. This is known as the permissive action of Leptin.

Incorrect answers:

A. Lower levels of leptin are usually associated with amenorrhea and as the patient has already established and regular cycle, lower levels of leptin are also associated with lower BMI.

B. High levels of glutamate surrounding puberty is normal and is unlikely to have caused the conditions.

D. Lower levels of glutamate does not contribute to advancement of puberty in obese patients.

Reference : Williams gynecology 4th edition chapter 17 page number:378- 379

choices.text: Acts like natural FSH, and has effect on progesterone, as well as estrogen progesterone and thus leads to ovulation
May lead to osteoporosis, hot flushes and nausea
Must be given in pulsatile manner

questions.text: A patient comes with complaints associated with delayed puberty. The attending doctor chooses to start her on leuprolide acetate. Which of the following is true?
questions.solution:
GnRH analogues(Leuprolide) must be given in pulsatile manner for the treatment of likely causes of delayed puberty.

Options A,B,C are not true with respect to GnRH analogues.

Note: GnRH analogues given constantly is used for the treatment of precocious puberty.

Reference: William's Gynecology, Reproductive endocrinology, 4th edition. Chapter 16, page number:335-344.

choices.text: FSH: LH ratio 1:2 is to be expected
FSH: LH ratio to be checked on Day 2-3 of the cycle
Progesterone synthesis begins: 12 hours prior to the LH surge
Life span of the corpus luteum would be 10-12 days

questions.text: During a normal menstrual cycle, which of the following is true?
questions.solution:
It's a fact

Incorrect answers:

A: FSH:LH ratio 1:2 is a sign of PCOD.

C: Progesterone synthesis normally begins 36 hours before the LH surge.

D: Life span is 10-12 days in a pregnant female; the normal non pregnant female Corpus luteum would have a life span of 12-14 days.

Reference: William's Gynecology, Reproductive endocrinology, 4th edition. Chapter 16, page number:336-340.

choices.text: 45XO: short stature caused by mutation in SHOX containing Gene
46XX: normal height of patient but streak ovaries, likelihood of horseshoe kidney decreases
46XX: short stature with webbed neck and streak ovaries: high chances of developing gonadoblastoma
45XO: treatment initial low dose estrogen followed by cyclical estrogen and progesterone

questions.text: All are true for gonadal dysgenesis except?
questions.solution:
46 XX with short stature and webbed neck along with Streak ovaries likely indicates one of the mosaic presentation of Turner syndrome. In this condition chances of development of gonadoblastoma are low since the Y chromosome is absent.

  • XY form likely has high chances of developing gonadoblastoma.

Incorrect answers: these are applicable to gonadal dysgenesis:

A: 45 XO has suboptimal estrogen which leads to late epiphyseal closure, we should lead to a taller height in the patient. However, due to SHOX mutation the patient remains short statured.

B:46 XX with normal height but streak Ovary indicates pure gonadal dysgenesis in this condition the associated are normally such as horseshoe kidneys coarctation of aorta as well as autoimmune diseases such as diabetes or Hashimoto's are unlikely.

D: Turner syndrome treatment should be initial lower doses of estrogen therapy followed by cyclical estrogen and progesterone leading to withdrawal bleeding which appears as menstruation.

Reference: William's Gynecology. 4th edition. Chapter 19, page number:411-413.

questions.text: Which of the following features are not a risk factor associated with PCOS as well as protective factor for ovarian cancer?
questions.solution:
Ovarian cancers and endometrial cancers are estrogen excess conditions and thus are protected by the factors which reduced estrogen levels as well as ovulation.

PCOS is a condition worsened by insulin excess as well as anovulation inducing factors.

However both these conditions are associated with a higher body mass index.

Incorrect answers:

  1. Anastrozole is an aromatase inhibitor and thus leads to reduced conversion of androgen to estradiol in granulosa cells; which is a risk factor for high androgen state of PCOS, but protective for Ovarian tumors which are high estrogen states.
  2. Smoking inhibits aromatase enzyme and thus is a risk factor for PCOS but protective for ovarian cancer.
  3. OCPs bring about anovulation and are a protective factor in both the conditions.

Reference: William's gynaecology, 4th edition, chapter 18, page number:389; chapter 36, page number:758-759.

questions.text: Which of the following congenital uterine anomalies is most commonly linked with recurrent pregnancy loss?
questions.solution:
Go through the table for better understanding

Class: I

Mullerian anomaly: Mullerian agenesis

Characteristic Features Both mullerian ducts absent, only ovaries present

Class: II

Mullerian anomaly: Unicornuate uterus

Characteristic Features: 1 Fallopian tube,1/2 uterus,1/2 cervix,1/2 vagina

HSG findings

Gross findings:

Class: III

Mullerian anomaly: Didelphic uterus

Characteristic Features 2 Fallopian tubes, 2 uterus, 2 cervix, 1 vagina

HSG findings:

Gross findings:

Class: IV

Mullerian anomaly: Bicornuate uterus

Characteristic Features: 2 fallopian tube, 2 uterus, 1 cervix, 1 vagina, abnormal external contour.

HSG findings:

Gross findings:

Class: V

Mullerian anomaly: Septate uterus

Characteristic Features: 2 uterine cavities divided by septum, 2 fallopian tubes, 1 cervix, normal external contour

HSG findings:

Gross findings:

Class: VI

Mullerian anomaly: Arcuate uterus

Characteristic Features: Everything is normal except the fundus has a dimple in the centre.

HSG findings:

Gross findings:

Class: VII

Mullerian anomaly: DES(Diethylstillbesterone) related

Characteristic Features Hypoplastic uterus,T shaped uterus,cervical collars, Adenocarcinoma cervix and clear cell carcinoma of vagina

HSG findings:

Gross findings:

OPTION a. Unicornuate uterus: A unicornuate uterus has a single uterine horn and is associated with a higher risk of complications such as preterm birth and fetal malpresentation, but it is less commonly linked with recurrent pregnancy loss compared to a septate uterus.

OPTION b. Bicornuate uterus: A bicornuate uterus has two uterine cavities,two fallopian tubes,single cervix and vagina which can increase the risk of miscarriage and preterm birth, but it is less frequently associated with recurrent pregnancy loss than a septate uterus.

OPTION c. Septate uterus: A septate uterus is characterized by a septum dividing the uterine cavity partially or completely. It is the most commonly associated congenital anomaly with recurrent pregnancy loss because the septum can interfere with implantation and increase the risk of miscarriage.

OPTION d. Arcuate uterus: An arcuate uterus has a minor indentation in the uterine fundus but is generally associated with fewer complications and is less commonly linked with recurrent pregnancy loss compared to a septate uterus. It has the best reproductive outcome out of all Mullerian anomalies.

Type: Must know

Topic: Mullerian anomalies

Reference: Williams Gynaecology 3rd edition, Page number. 449

questions.text: A 19-year-old male presents with delayed puberty, anosmia, and low testosterone levels. Physical examination reveals a lack of secondary sexual characteristics. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
OPTION A: Klinefelter Syndrome is characterized by hypogonadism, small testes, gynecomastia, and tall stature. Patients usually have normal sense of smell and may show mild to moderate learning difficulties. It is associated with high FSH and LH levels and low testosterone but does not present with anosmia.

OPTION B: Kallmann Syndrome is a genetic condition characterized by hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (low levels of gonadotropins like FSH and LH) and anosmia (loss of sense of smell). It is due to a failure of GnRH neurons to migrate properly, leading to delayed or absent puberty and low testosterone levels in males, along with lack of secondary sexual characteristics. Anosmia is a distinguishing feature of this condition.

OPTION C: Turner Syndrome affects females and is characterized by short stature, ovarian dysgenesis, and a lack of sexual development. It is not associated with anosmia or low testosterone levels in males.

OPTION D: Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (AIS) is a condition where individuals with a 46, XY karyotype are resistant to androgens. It presents with normal levels of testosterone, but due to resistance, individuals may have female external genitalia, lack male secondary sexual characteristics, and have undescended testes. Anosmia is not a feature of AIS.

Reference: Speroff's Gynaecology 9th edition, Page number:782

choices.text: At puberty, pubic and axillary hair will be corresponding to tanner stage 1
External genitalia rudimentary: Treatment must include oestrogen plus progestin therapy
Bilateral laparoscopic gonadectomy to be planned after 2-3 years
If clitoromegaly present: gonadectomy as soon as possible

questions.text: A 14 year old female presents with primary amenorrhea, showing positive apparent secondary sexual characteristics with breast developed to tanner stage 4. On karyotyping the genotype comes to 46XY. Pick the odd one out.
questions.solution:
• Primary amenorrhea at the age of puberty with positive secondary sexual characters such as breast development to Tanner stage 4 or 5 along with a carrier type of 46 XY indicates androgen insensitivity syndrome.
  • In this case A, C&D are correct and applicable to the condition.
  • Androgen insensitivity syndrome may be complete incomplete or Reifenstein syndrome.
  • In the case of rudimentary external genitalia treatment need not include Progestin as uterus is absent, since it is the case of complete androgen insensitivity and thus there is no risk of development of endometrial cancer.

Incorrect answers:

A: Pubic and axillary hair it will be corresponding to stage 1: in androgen insensitivity syndrome as the hormone needed for pubic hair and axillary hair is an androgen.

C: For cases of complete androgen insensitivity bilateral laparoscopic gonadectomy should be planned after puberty that is around 16 to 18 years of age.

D: Presidents of Clitoromegaly indicates in complete androgen insensitivity syndrome when combined with Tanner stage 4 or 5 breast development, in this condition connectivity should be done at puberty or as soon as possible as the patient is sensitive to slide amount of testosterone.

Reference: William's gynecology, 4th edition, chapter 19, page number:413-416.
